meanings.definition: To strike or propel with the foot
meanings.sent1: I like to kick the ball during soccer practice.
meanings.sent2: She kicked the door open when her hands were full.
meanings.sent3: He gave the stubborn vending machine a kick to make it work.
meanings.sent4: The engine finally started after a hard kick to the starter.
meanings.sent5: The horse kicked wildly, trying to break free from the reins.

meanings.definition: A sudden forceful jolt or impact
meanings.sent1: The car hit a bump and gave us a kick.
meanings.sent2: He felt a kick in his chest as the roller coaster descended.
meanings.sent3: The unexpected kick in the road made the journey more exciting.
meanings.sent4: The kick of the explosion sent debris flying everywhere.
meanings.sent5: The kick of the earthquake shook the entire building.

meanings.definition: A feeling of excitement or exhilaration
meanings.sent1: Winning the game gave her a kick of joy.
meanings.sent2: The surprise party was a real kick for everyone.
meanings.sent3: The kick of anticipation before the concert was thrilling.
meanings.sent4: The kick of adrenaline fueled his performance on stage.
meanings.sent5: The kick of excitement was palpable in the air.
